Comment: A question to those that know about the legal terms (maybe lawyers maybe not): Can one deport a citizen from the country that they are a citizen of?  I (not a lawyer) would imagine that deportation is only something a country can do to a non-citizen. Expelling a citizen from a country would be exile, right?   Similar to how if I have a guest over at my house and I then decide that they need to be removed from my house I can 'send them home'. This works in common speech: X guest made me angry so I sent them back home.   But one cannot 'send home' a roommate, live in partner, child, or pet as they don't have a different home. One can expel one of these people (or animals) from their home though this is seen much more negatively.  Napoleon was not deported to Saint Helena, he was expelled or exiled to Saint Helena.

Comment: I absolutely understand. These days, my cousins and the rest of the family have created something like a Truman Show version of reality for my aunt. We know it would all be too much for her. She can probably still recall every detail—from the attacks on universities to the arrests of judges and the registration of ADHD youth it was called Aktion T4 in Germany . It’s all a copy-paste of Nazi Germany, the same regime that took members of her immediate family, her home, and basically her entire life.   We don't want her to be afraid because this time she would be afraid for her kids and grandkids and grand grandkids and that's even more painful. We have family members in the USA , and some of them are members of LGBTQ+ community - we are all afraid.
Author: pianoavengers
